subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... Or some more complex combinations, depending on what people do with LOT, CLOTH, THOUGHT, and PALM.  For me, LOT = PALM and gets Ah, whereas THOUGHT = CLOTH
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> 1. Americans will use Ah where a British speaker would use On or Awl.

Or some more complex combinations, depending on what people do with
LOT, CLOTH, THOUGHT, and PALM. For me, LOT = PALM and gets Ah,
whereas THOUGHT = CLOTH and gets Awe.

> 2. Where Americans use Ash for words like "bath," British speakers use
> Ah. This difference cannot be helped.

Eastern New England has BATH = PALM too, so it's not strictly a
British/American split.

--
A rose by any other name John Cowan
may smell as sweet, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
but if you called it an onion cowan@...
you'd get cooks very confused. --RMS
